headline: Who will Stop You?  On Power, Pretense, and the State of the Republic
author: Publius

content:
There are moments when the question before a Republic is no longer one of legality, but of recognition.

This is one of them.

A newly released recording, first reported by the Atlanta Journal-Constitution and corroborated by WSB-TV, reveals a December 7, 2020 conversation in which a defeated president pressed the Speaker of the Georgia House to summon a special legislative session, not to legislate, not to remedy a proven defect, but to undo an election already decided and certified.

The method proposed is as instructive as the goal.

Call it transparency. Call it an inquiry. Say it is about uncovering fraud.

And when the law stands in the way?

Who's gonna stop you?

This is not the language of confusion. It is the language of entitlement.

— Alexander Hamilton, Federalist No. 78 (1788)

“There is no liberty, if the power of judging be not separated from the legislative and executive powers.”

It assumes that the law is not a boundary, but an obstacle, something to be navigated with the right phrasing and the right posture. It treats constitutional limits not as restraints binding power, but as inconveniences binding only those too timid to ignore them.

The suggestion of a cover story is itself the confession. Honest acts require no disguise. Legitimate authority does not need to be smuggled through procedure under false pretenses. When a man advises others to clothe an action in acceptable language, it is because he knows the action itself cannot stand in daylight.

We should be clear about what this was not.

It was not a dispute over close margins. It was not a request for recounts. It was not a legal challenge argued before a court.

It was an attempt to enlist a legislature as an instrument of reversal, to use the appearance of lawful process to negate the expressed will of the people. The aim was not investigation, but nullification. The means was not persuasion, but pressure.

Those who shrug and say it failed miss the point entirely.

A Republic does not depend for its survival on the failure of bad acts. It depends on the refusal to attempt them at all. When restraint disappears, when the only remaining question is whether someone else will intervene, the moral architecture of self-government has already begun to rot.

The most revealing part of the exchange is not the demand, but the assumption beneath it: that power may test the limits until stopped. That legitimacy flows not from consent, but from audacity. That if one pushes hard enough, someone else bears responsibility for saying no.

This is the creed of every would-be despot.

History is unambiguous on this point. Tyranny does not arrive announcing itself as such. It arrives insisting it seeks only order, only clarity, only transparency. It arrives wrapped in familiar forms, using established institutions as tools against their own purpose. It keeps the ceremonies while draining them of meaning.

The danger, then, is not confined to the man who made the call.

It lies in the normalization of the logic it expressed.

If elections are provisional until power concedes them, they are not elections. If legislatures may be summoned under false pretenses to overturn outcomes, they are not representative bodies. If law restrains only those who respect it, then law no longer governs.

The founders warned us that liberty is rarely extinguished in a single blow. More often, it is worn down by precedent, by excuse, by the quiet acceptance of acts that would once have been unthinkable. A people do not wake up enslaved. They wake up accustomed.

This recording matters not because it shocked us, but because it clarifies. It strips away the rhetoric and leaves the premise exposed: that power, once held, is owed continuity, and that the people's judgment is merely advisory.

A Republic cannot survive that premise.

The question now is not whether this conduct was improper. It plainly was. The question is whether we still recognize it as disqualifying. Whether we still believe that losing an election ends a claim to authority. Whether we still understand that no office, however high, confers the right to ask who will stop you.

For in a functioning Republic, the answer is simple.

The law stops you. The Constitution stops you. And when those fail, the people must remember that they exist not to excuse power, but to restrain it.

If we forget that, then the question posed in that call will not remain rhetorical for long.
